Award.AbstractNarration:
A three-week long summer graduate program on "Algebraic Geometry for Applications" will take place in Georgia Institute of Technology from June 18 to July 6, 2012. The program will focus on Polynomial Optimization and Real Algebraic Geometry, Computer Algebra and Numerical Algebraic Geometry, Tropical Geometry, and their applications. Institute for Mathematics and Applications (IMA) provides funding for IMA participating institutions. The supplemental NSF funding will be used to cover students from non-participating institutions.

Techniques and algorithmic methods from algebraic geometry have been making an impact on applied mathematics and engineering in recent years. With large computations now possible due to the growing power of modern computers and vast availability of computational resources, the applied mathematics community is opening up to the machinery of algebra. This summer program is aimed at preparing the next generation of mathematicians in the area of applied algebraic geometry.

For more information see https://sites.google.com/site/imaaga2012

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the summer of 2012, a summer program for graduate students "Algebraic Geometry for Applications" was organized by Anton Leykin, Greg Blekherman, and Josephine Yu.  It was funded  by the Institute of Mathematics and Its Applications and by the National Science Foundation. 

 

 

The goal of the program was to gather the next generation of applied algebraic geometers to provide them with advanced training and introduce them to the community. A diverse group of students came to Georgia Tech for three weeks: forty-seven students from US and abroad, including Germany, Austria, Finland, China, and Korea. Nine local students from Georgia Tech and Georgia State University also participated. The students were at different stages of their PhD programs.

 

 

The students received an invaluable opportuinity to actively interact and recieve hands on mentoring from leading experts. They were given daily lectures by the three organizers and seven prominent researchers in the field. The lectures covered basic and advanced material in three areas of applied algebraic geometry: 

  1. Polynomial optimization;

  2. Computer algebra and numerical solving of the polynomial systems;

  3. Tropical and discrete geometry.

Students vigorously and enthusiastically participated in daily exercise sessions.  An online wiki was created for students to share questions and answersto the problems. Additionally software tutorials provided introduction to advanced mathematical software. Five  postdoctoral assistants provided additional help and mentoring. Additionally we held mentoring activities focused on career development.
